The contribution to tropospheric SO2 from continuously degassing and explosive volcanoes is treated in the same way as in AM3 (Donner et al., 2011).

Monahan et al. 1986; Martensson et al. 2003
Other: land use change specified according to LUH2 forcing data

Land use transitions from LUH2 forcing data set are imposed on the vegetation anually; the land use types employed by the model are primary (natural, undisturbed), croplands, pastures, and secondary (disturbed but recovering) vegetation. Croplands and pastures are harvested, indirectly influencing all surface properties, including albedo.
Advection: finite volume with vertical lagrangian; Diffusion: implicit LU decomposition; Convection: explicit convective mass flux;
SO4 precursor, organics and black carbon aerosols emitted from CMIP-6 emission inventories; sea-salt and dust mechanically emitted from the surface as a function of surface winds.
Sulfate production uses a simplified scheme with prescribed O3 and radicals varying monthly and interannually and are extracted from CMIP-5 historical simulation

Absorption coefficients are given at 550 nm for dry aerosols in units of m2/kg. Dust is divided in 5 bins. The absorption coefficient for each 5 size bins defined by minimum and maximum radii in parenthesis: dust1 (0.1-1 um)=0.069; dust2 (1-2 um)=0.056; dust3 (2-3 um)=0.046; dust4 (3-6 um)=0.035; dust5 (6-10)=0.026. Black carbon is internally mixed with sulfate and the optical properties of their internal mixing depend on relative humidity, as for each 5 bins of sea-salt, and phyllic organic carbon.
Volume weight average of optical properties (extinction coeff, single scattering albedo and asymmetry) of sulfate (assumed entirely ammonium sulfate) and black carbon
sulfate, organics, black carbon, sea-salt, dust

The model prognose mass distribution of five aerosol types including sulfate, dust, black carbon, organic carbon, and sea salt based on their emissions (and precursor emissions), chemical production for sulfate and secondary organics, dry and wet (rainout and washout) deposition, transport by advection, and dry and wet convection.
U, V,  T, Qv, Ql, Qi, P, convective mass flux, precipitation, boundary layer height
land-sea mask, dust source function, ocean productivity, leaf area index
C96 (Cubed-sphere topology with 96x96 grid boxes per cube face)
The model was tuned to improve simulations of present-day climatological distribution of aerosol properties (i.e. surface concentration, aerosol optical depth, vertical extinction coefficient)
Other: Two-level sponge layer and flexible lid
Other: Lin and Rood (1997) C-D grid

The basic shortwave and longwave radiation algorithms are described in Freidenreich and
Ramaswamy (1999) and Schwarzkopf and Ramaswamy (1999), respectively,
modified as in GFDL Global Atmospheric Model Development Team (2004). Modifications to both schemes are described in Zhao et al (2018b).
 The principal changes for longwave scheme  are: 
1) use of HITRAN 2012 line data
2) use of mt_ckd 2.5 formulation for the H2O continuum
3) inclusion of the CO2 10 um band
4) capability to compute longwave CO2 absorption with amounts up to 10000 ppmv; CH4 absorption up to 6000 ppbv; N2O absorption up to 800 ppbv. 
 The principal changes for shortwave scheme  are: 
1) inclusion of shortwave water vapor continuum 
2) inclusion of new o2 bands
3) updated ESF parameters for H2O, now has 66 integration points rather than 38. 
4) CO2 now calculated with ESF
PBL convection described in Lock (2000) and GAMDT (2004). Double plume moist convection described in Zhao et al (2018b) and Bretherton et al (2004)
Double Plume scheme with one bulk plume for deep and one for shallow convection (Zhao et al 2018)
CAPE/WFN based: CAPE-Cloud Work Function: Based on the quasi-equilibrium of the free troposphere
modified UW Shallow Cumulus Scheme (Bretherton et. al 2004, Zhao et. al 2008, Zhao et. al 2018)
Tietke large-scale cloud scheme, Rotstayn microphysics

Large-scale cloud scheme is described in Tiedtke (1993) with the cloud microphysics described in Rotstayn (1997) and Rotstayn et al. (2000). Fluxes of large-scale rain and snow are diagnosed and the amount of precipitation flux inside and outside of clouds is tracked separately following Jakob and Klein (2000).
Prognostic cloud liquid, ice, amount, and drop number with parameterized sources and sinks
Other: prognostic cloud area, liquid, and ice for stratiform clouds; convective cloud area diagnosed from cumulus parameterizations
Tiedtke (1993) for stratiform clouds; Bretherton et al. (2004) for convective clouds
Tiedtke (1993) for stratiform clouds; Bretherton et al. (2004) for convective clouds
COSP version 1.4.1 was used for all CMIP6 experiments
Subgrid orographic drag parameterization is decribed in Garner (2005) and Zhao et. al (2018). Convective gravity wave parameterization is described in Alexander and Dunkerton (1999).
From Kopp et al. (2005, Solar Physics)
AMIP, prescribed SST and sea-ice concentration, atmosphere-land-vegetation coupled model

GFDL Atmosphere Model (version 4.0.1) is the Atmosphere and Land component of GFDL coupled model CM4.0 for use in CMIP6. The Atmospheric compoent is identifical to the AM4.0 model documented in Zhao et. al (2018a, 2018b). The vegetation, land and glacier models differ from AM4.0 in the following aspects: 1) dynamical vegetation was used instead the static vegetation used in AM4.0. 2) glacier albedo is retuned. 3) other minor tuning in the land model.

Model simulated present-day global top-of-atmsphere radiative fluxes are tuned towards the observational estimates from CERES. Model development focus on model performance in simulating present-day climatolgy such as precipitation, winds, TOA radiative fluxes.
Global mean OLR and SW absorption at top-of-atmosphere
No specific regional metrics/diagnostic of mean state are used in tuning the model. However, model development has used global RMSE of precipitation, TOA radiative flux for model evaluation.
CO, CH2O, NO, C3H6, isoprene, C2H6, C2H4, C4H10, terpenes, C3H8, acetone, CH3OH, C2H5OH, H2, SO2, NH3
CO, CH2O, NO, C3H6, isoprene, C2H6, C2H4, C4H10, terpenes, C3H8, acetone, CH3OH, C2H5OH, H2, SO2, NH3

Clear-sky photolysis frequencies are calculated using a multivariate interpolation table derived from the Tropospheric Ultraviolet-Visible radiation model (Madronich and Flocke, 1998), with an adjustment applied for the effects of large-scale clouds, as described by Brasseur et al. (1998).

The key difference in the light atmospheric chemistry model is the simplified chemical production of sulfate. This simplification reduces the number of tracers by a factor of 3, which allows maintaining sustainable throughput at high spatial resolution. Chemical production of sulfate is from oxidation of sulfur dioxide in the gas phase by OH, and in the aqueous phase by O3 and H2O2. The rate of aqueous-phase oxidation of sulfate by O3 and H2O2 depends on the solution pH (Seinfeld & Pandis, 1998). There is no explicit treatment of ozone chemistry. Instead, the monthly concentrations of O3 and other oxidants (OH, HO2 , and NO3 ) and the photolysis rate of H2O2 used by the sulfate chemistry are extracted and averaged over a 20 year climatology (1981–2000) simulated with AM3 (Naik et al., 2013). Fixed diurnal variations are imposed to the radicals with maximum during daytime for OH, HO2, jH2O2 and nightime for NO3. A step function is used for HO2 and NO3, and a sinusoidal variation with maximum at noon for OH and jH2O2.

Chemical production of sulfate is from oxidation of sulfur dioxide in the gas phase by OH, and in the aqueous phase by O3 and H2O2. The rate of aqueous-phase oxidation of sulfate by O3 and H2O2 depends on the solution pH (Seinfeld & Pandis, 1998). There is no explicit treatment of ozone chemistry. Instead, the monthly concentrations of O3 and other oxidants (OH, HO2 , and NO3 ) and the photolysis rate of H2O2 used by the sulfate chemistry are calculated from a 20 year climatology (1981–2000) simulated by AM3 (Naik et al., 2013).

Global dust emission is tuned. Dust emission is initiated when surface winds exceed a threshold of wind erosion. Emission parametrization depends at the cubic power on surface winds, which are resolution dependent. Therefore, a tuning is performed to match annual mean surface concentration with observed values measured by the University of Miami on islands spread around the world. For hygroscopic aerosols, a cap on maximum growth is assumed to avoid excessive particle size.
Global dust emission constant = 2x10^{-10} kg.s^2/m^5; Threshold of wind erosion=3.5 m/s; Max growth at 97% relative humidity
Soil type prescibed at each grid point
Soil type prescibed at each grid point
Bare soil albedo prescibed at each grid point
Distinction between direct and diffuse albedo
Leaves + fine roots + coarse roots + stems
Leaves, storage, fine roots, sapwood, heartwood
atmosphere-land coupled model, AMIP, dynamic vegetation, soil hydrology, land use

Land grid cells are partitioned to represent different land types: soil, lake, or glacier. The soil tile is further subdivied into different land use types such as croplands, pastures, primary and secondary lands (i.e. recovering after logging or agricultural abandonment). The fraction of each land-use tile changes annually according to historical reconstructions or future scenarios of land use from CMIP6 forcing. Soil water runoff is transported to the ocean by a grid-scale river and lake network. Prognostic variables for soil, lake, and overlaying constant-density snowpack are liquid content, ice content, and temperature (all vertically distributed). The soil is treated as a dual-domain (Beven & Germann, 1982), saturated-unsaturated, soil-bedrock continuum, in which matrix flow is governed by Richard’s equation (Hillel, 1980), and both infiltration and parameterized subgrid discharge to rivers may be facilitated by idealized macropores. Lakes are represented by one or more vertical columns, with density-driven stratification and overturning. Prognostic variables for each river reach are depth-averaged liquid mass, solid mass, and sensible heat content. Rivers flow according to the hydraulic geometry of Leopold and Maddock (1953). Prognostic variables for vegetation are mass of carbon in each of five plant compartments (leaves, fine roots, heartwood, sapwood, and labile), and liquid and solid water storage and temperature on leaves. Vegetation type (C3 or C4 grass, temperate deciduous, tropical, or cold evergreen tree) is determined by plant total carbon and climate (Shevliakova et al., 2009). Photosynthesis and stomatal conductance are determined mechanistically (Leuning, 1995).
land-use gross transitions from LUH2 CMIP6 data set, including shifting cultivation, primary and secondary wood harvesting. land cover is determined by dynamic vegetation model for each tile

In coastal grid cells a partial land cover is allowed, i.e.  only part of the grid cell can be land covered, the rest is ocean. Land within each grid cell can contain a fraction of open water (lake), a fraction of land ice (glacier); the rest is soil/vegetation covered. Dynamic vegetation model predicts the vegetetion properties, which under unsuitable conditions may lead to vegetatoin diaback and  bare soil. Land use comonent generates new land use tiles and/or changes their fractional area.
Within land component, energy is conserved. For a 30-year experiment, Milly et al. (2014) found a balance residual of -10^-6 W m^-2.
Within land component, water is conserved. For a 30-year experiment, Milly et al. (2014) found a balance residual of -10^-4 mm/y.
within land component, carbon is conserved
Physical state updated on the same time step as atmospheric physics (every 1800 s); vegetation dynamics and rivers use daily time step.
Flux corrections are not applicable to the model, since SST is prescribed.
AM2, see GFDL-GAMDT, 2004, Journal of Climate
AM3, see Donner et al., 2011, Journal of Climate

AM4 contains two versions wth different levels of complexity in atmospheric chemistry. The light chemistry version (AM4.0) is used in CM4 while the full chemistry version (AM4.1) is used in ESM4. AM4.0 differs from AM3 in the following: 1) higher horizontal resolution; 2) reduced chemical gas tracers; 3) prescribed ozone; 4) improved radiative transfer model; 5) improved parameterizations in mountain gravity wave drag, moist convection, aerosol-cloud interactions.

FMS (Flexible Modeling System) coupler exchanges fluxes among various independent components (atmosphere, ocean, sea ice, land) ensuring the conservation of properties (e.g. mass, energy) and numerical stability.
AMIP, prescribed SST and sea-ice concentration, atmosphere-land-vegetation coupled model

This is the Atmosphere and Land component (AM4.0.1) of GFDL coupled model CM4.0 for use in CMIP6. The Atmospheric component is identifical to the AM4.0 model documented in Zhao et. al (2018a, 2018b). The vegetation, land and glacier models differ from AM4.0 in the following aspects: 1) dynamical vegetation was used instead the static vegetation used in AM4.0. 2) glacier albedo is retuned. 3) other minor tuning in the land model.

Model simulated present-day global top-of-atmsphere radiative fluxes are tuned towards the observational estimates from CERES (EBAF-Ed2.8). Model development focused on model performance in simulating present-day climatolgy such as precipitation, winds, TOA radiative fluxes.
Global mean OLR and SW absorption at top-of-atmosphere
No specific regional metrics/diagnostic of mean state are used in tuning model. However, model development has used global RMSE of precipitation, TOA radiative flux for model evaluation.

No observed trend metrics/diagnostics are used in tuning model/compoent. However, model Cess sensitivity and aerosol forcings are monitored during model development. This could indirectly affect coupled model simulation of 20th century.

Dissipation of kinetic energy due to dynamical core is corrected globally by adding a heating rate to the atmosphere. Energy conserved by dynamical core and physics parameterization are not identifical. More details documented in Zhao et. al (2018).
There is no specific enforcement of global heat conservation. But when averaged over multiple years, the global heat flux difference between TOA and surface is typically less than 0.1 W/m2.
FMS coupler conserves heat across ocean/atmosphere interface
FMS coupler conserves heat across land/atmosphere interface
FMS coupler conserves heat across sea ice/atmosphere interface
FMS coupler conserves heat across land/ocean interface by passing heat carried by rivers to the ocean.
FMS coupler conserves fresh water across land/atmosphere interface

Runoff from land enters into river network, which transports it to the discharge points (river mouths) and passes the fresh water flux to the ocean. River network interacts with the atmopshere through the fluxes from/to open water fractions of the land grid cell.
River network carries all runoff to the ocean.
To avoid long-term unbound accumulation of snow on land, snow accumulated above certain thershold is converted to runoff and put into the river network.
